update.description:
Extending the work from pull request #134 and pull request #138, this PR starts a new section in the documentation describing the internal design and some implementation details about the library.

In particular, this PR focuses on Discovery. The 2nd part will describe `NodeShared`.

Special thanks to @nampi , @amtj for their contribution.

You can visualize the generated documentation clicking on `View file` or here:

http://ignition-transport.readthedocs.io/en/dev_doc/development/development.html
update.title: Development doc - Part1: Discovery

content.html: It looks OK in the published version.

content.raw: Does this link become valid when the documentation is published?
content.html: Does this link become valid when the documentation is published?

content.raw: Oh, this is to show that `Shared` can also send and receive its own data using ZMQ bypassing Discovery. Maybe it requires some clarification.
content.html: Oh, this is to show that Shared can also send and receive its own data using ZMQ bypassing Discovery. Maybe it requires some clarification.

content.raw: I think that this character "⇅"  shows that communication happens in both directions. My question is about "⇑".
content.html: I think that this character "⇅" shows that communication happens in both directions. My question is about "⇑".

content.raw: Just arrows to show that communication happens in both directions
content.html: Just arrows to show that communication happens in both directions

content.raw: Why do you use global links? I think it is better to use relative links, because the address of WebPage can change.
content.html: Why do you use global links? I think it is better to use relative links, because the address of WebPage can change.

content.raw: What do the columns beginning with "⇑" mean?
content.html: What do the columns beginning with "⇑" mean?

content.raw:
Minor edit:

If the topic'***s*** scope is

Minor edit: 

call even if we can receive ***data*** from multiple interfaces.
content.html:
Minor edit:

call even if we can receive data from multiple interfaces.

content.raw:
I think it is better to use relative links, because the address of WebPage can change.

```
#!bash

:doc:`here <../environment_variables/env_variables>`
```
content.html:
I think it is better to use relative links, because the address of WebPage can change.

:doc:`here <../environment_variables/env_variables>`
